An experiment is performed to study the potential difference across the capacitor as it discharges through a resistor. A circuit is to be constructed with the following available equipment: a single ideal battery of potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, a single voltmeter, a single resistor of resistance <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, a single uncharged variable capacitor set to capacitance <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, and one or more switches as needed.(a) Using the symbols shown, draw a schematic diagram of a circuit that can charge the capacitor and may also be used to study the potential difference across the capacitor as it discharges through the resistor.

The capacitor is fully charged by the battery. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the capacitor starts discharging through the resistor.(b) Show that the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> across the capacitor as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is <math alttext="delta V sub C, of t, equals, delta V sub 0, times e raised to the negative of the fraction t over uppercase R C, end fraction, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></msup></math> as the capacitor discharges.

(c) The experiment is performed using a resistor of <math alttext="uppercase R equals 150 kilo-ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>kΩ</mi></math>. Data for the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> across the capacitor as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are recorded and a plot of <math alttext="the natural log of the fraction with numerator delta V sub C, and denominator delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is created on the graph below.i. Draw the best-fit line for the data.
ii. Using the best-fit line, calculate a value for the unknown capacitance <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The capacitor is adjusted so that the surface area of the plates is increased, and the experiment is repeated. Would the slope of the best-fit line in the second experiment be more steep, less steep, or unchanged compared to the slope of the best-fit line in part (c)?___ More steep ___ Less steep ___ UnchangedBriefly justify your answer.

(e) The ideal battery is then replaced with a non-ideal battery with internal resistance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and the experiment is repeated.i.
